ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned the fundamentals of real analysis. This course felt like the gateway to the higher level, pure mathematics that one doesn't typically see in combinatorics (Math 244), linear algebra (Math 225), or calculus (Math 120).
I can analysis all the vectors.
I learned about the theory behind derivatives and integrals, how to integrate manifolds and k-forms, etc.
I learned about differentiation and integration on manifolds, as well as proof techniques.
I learned about advanced calculus topics such as orientation, exterior derivatives, manifolds, parametrization, the implicit function differentiation theorem and much more.
Intro vector analysis
Explored vector calculus, integration on manifolds, and differential forms. Learned a lot about math beyond multivariable calculus.
Math analysis, proof methods, etc.
Vector analysis, manifolds, how to better write proofs more rigorously
An understanding of some basic set theory and topology concepts, what a manifold and a differential form are, how to take exterior derivatives.
This was my first proof-based class, so I learned how to think abstractly about mathematical concepts and vector spaces.
Fundamentals and proofs behind calculus
Vector Analysis, so basically everything covered in MATH 120 but this time with rigorous proofs. I also learned a lot about proof writing and proof strategies in general.
I learned a lot about the theory behind derivatives and integration. Also got exposed to manifolds which is a really cool concept.
Fundamentals of proofs, vector calculus (including differentiation, integration, and a better understanding of manifolds)
a good and thorough knowledge of vector calculus
A prerequisite for 300 level analysis course, although this course will be obsolete soon as the math department is reorganizing the sequence.
I had my first taste of proof-writing in mathematics.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I think this goes for every math class but when there's dead silence it means no one understood what just happened. I know it's really easy to get excited and go off about a topic but a lot of the detailed understanding actually came from OH. That being said I think Caglar has been by far the best math instructor I have had because he (to some degree) understood that.

The course is very straightforward and expectations were clear from the beginning. We had a problem set every week and the due dates were flexible depending on what we learned each week which was helpful. There were plenty of office hours every week and they were all very helpful. Lectures were also very clear and concise with plenty of examples that helped with understanding the material. Caglar was eager to answer any questions and was engaging during lecture.

Strengths: Very organized, appropriately paced, and easy-to-follow
Weaknesses: Lots of assignments were pure calculations and it would have been nice to put these in context (like how it could be applied in the real world)

I think the course was very close to ideal as Caglar managed to teach it. A big strength was that the TA would walk us through the pset answers. This meant that on one hand we were able to avoid any stress associated with trying to solve a pset and on the other hand we were able to understand the concepts really well. Also, another big strength were the post-exam corrections. One possible improvement I could suggest is that given that the final is only worth 20% of the grade, in future semesters it could be placed during the last week of classes so that students could do corrections and raise their grade over reading and exam period. Also, I think it would be a good idea if lectures were recorded during future semesters as well. The recordings really facilitated my revisions before exams.
Good coverage of content! Wouldnt change a thing
The course had an amazing TA and professor which made this class more enjoyable than most math courses.
I enjoyed the course and the idea of having exam corrections.

This course assumes a knowledge of proof writing that is often not present, and could benefit from some concrete "first you write this, then this, then this" examples on that front. There are also elements that require knowledge of linear algebra concepts covered in application-based linear algebra but NOT in proof-based linear algebra, which caused some confusion for the students.

Additionally, the second half of the course, while it requires knowledge of the material covered in the first half, could really be its own course. I know the introductory sequence is in the process of being restructured, and I hope that in the future the material in this course will be split across two courses. 

I did appreciate the time given to set theory/topology concepts as well as a pset that reviewed necessary concepts from linear algebra, as those were both very helpful in grounding us in the new material.
I thought the breakout rooms were very conducive to learning and practicing concepts.
Caglar was definitely a strength of the course! Really engaging lectures and very clear explanations. Problem sets were not that hard if you paid attention in the class

I thought this course was taught very well. Caglar taught at a good pace and was very clear. There were also lots of office hours which were super helpful (the peer tutor Fernando was GREAT). Sometimes the problem sets could be a bit much because we didn't really have a break after exams, but other than that I really enjoyed this course.

I would have preferred if this class was more theoretical. It is definitely more theoretical than ENAS 194 or S&DS 241, but it is no where near as theoretical as MATH 225. A lot of proofs are skimmed over & the psets & exams were more computation based, at least with this prof.
The live lectures were engaging and I felt encouraged to ask questions. Office hours (with Professor Uyanik and the peer tutor) were also especially helpful.
The teacher was phenomenal. No complaints
The course is clear and well organized in the topics that it did teach, although I did not find the material challenging. I think we could have covered a bit more material.
More in-class exercises would have helped me to learn the skills better.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: idk
The live lectures were engaging, and the many office hours throughout the week were extremely helpful for completing assignments and preparing for exams.
Recorded lectures with lecture notes posted
Super available TA

Making recordings of lectures and copies of the lecture notes available was very helpful - both for the occasions when I had to miss class and the times when I needed to review something from my notes. I did not find the breakout rooms during lecture especially helpful or engaging, as my fellow students weren't really interested in group work.

The peer tutor office hours on Zoom were also extremely helpful in understanding the homework.

I had an extra layer of stress added during exams by the fact that there was a limited window of time allowed to submit my scanned document and that I had to remain on Zoom until I did so. This created issues as my bandwidth is severely decreased by Zoom so retrieving the photos from my phone, downloading from the cloud and uploading to Gradescope always left we with seconds to spare.

The virtual lectures actually worked very well because it was easier to read Caglar's shared screen than a blackboard. I also liked that there was the option to watch them asynchronously. I usually attended lectures live, but it was nice to have some flexibility.
Its good that the lectures are recorded.
Office hours and recording the lectures
I loved how the lecture notes were posted and recorded
Professor Uyanik is accommodating towards the difficulties of remote learning and is very available for office hours and extra help.
Virtual class succeeded during COVID.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: As someone who is not majoring in pure mathematics, I struggle to see how most of the content from this course will be beneficial in the future. However, this course provided a solid opportunity to brush up on my linear algebra and multivariable calculus skills that I would have otherwise forgotten.
If they are a math major yes. To anyone else no.
Yes, it is a doable math course with lots of support.

Yes, only if you plan on taking higher-level math (or if it is required for your major) as the content in this course did not seem very applicable. Otherwise, it may feel like you are learning something that you probably will never apply in the real world.
Only if it is taught by Caglar, he was by far the best math teacher I've ever had.
Yes! Especially students interested in upper level math!
Yes to get a better background in math

I struggled with completing the exams in the time allotted, and felt the problems required more writing than could comfortably and cleanly be accomplished in time. I would recommend this course to students who are already thoroughly grounded in both proof-writing and linear algebra, and I do think it helps if you have been exposed to some set theory as well beforehand.
Absolutely, a fantastic course to learn proof-based math for the first time.
Yes!! Definitely take it!! Ver fun class and probably the last one before you get into heavy proofs classes
I definitely would recommend MATH 250 to another student. If they enjoyed MATH 120 and want to learn more about similar material, MATH 250 is a great course to take.
I would recommend this course to anyone who wants to learn about theory behind multivariable calculus.
Yes! I though the material was approachable and interesting.
Yes, calculus 4 is a very good class to take

The math department is reorganizing the analysis track as I am writing this, so this will become obsolete soon. The course is a prerequisite to the 300 level analysis courses, and it teaches the relevant skills.
I would, as it introduces oncoming math students to proof-writing,\.
